metadata.title: Augmentative and Alternative Communication  LiteracyEvaluation and intervention services to provide reading instruction and intervention to children who use augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) who are learning to read and/or have below-average  reading abilities
description: AAC is a system for communication that supplements or replaces verbal communication (speech) and includes four main components: symbols, aids, strategies, and techniques(1) –Symbols include objects, drawings, photographs, and print (i.e., words, letters, sentences)(1) –Aids can be relatively simple (e.g., communication boards) or complex devices (e.g., electronic devices) for transmitting or receiving messages(1) –Strategies refer to the methods by which symbols can be conveyed in the easiest, most efficient manner. For example, symbol selection methods (linear or row column scanning) and keyboard arrangements are considered "strategies" that affect the rate of symbol selection(1) –Techniques refer to the ways in which the messages are selected for transmission (e.g., direct selection, scanning)(1)

Children with developmental and physical disabilities who use AAC are a heterogeneous group with complex communication needs arising from a variety of etiologies, such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD), cerebral palsy, and Down syndrome. Due to an increased focus on early intervention, the population of children who use AAC has changed in recent years to include much younger children, children with a greater range of disabilities, and children from more diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds(45)
For detailed information on AAC assessment and intervention for communication disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on AAC and specific disorders
indications: The child uses AAC and is learning to read or has below-average reading skills and requires supplemental intervention. Students with physical and developmental disabilities are at risk for having poor reading or no reading skills; many have difficulties in communication skills that form the basis for reading, such as phonology, morphology, semantics, syntax, and pragmatics(2,3)

For AAC users, reading development might be further hindered by a child’s reduced access to print, reduced ability to actively participate in class or in shared book reading at home, lack of comprehensive literacy instruction, and isolation from peers during whole-class  literacy instruction(3,4,5,46)

reimbursement: In the United States, applications for AAC devices can be submitted by a speech-language  pathologist (SLP) or a durable medical equipment provider to Medicare, Medicaid, vocational rehabilitation services, and other funding sources. See http://www.aacfundinghelp.com/  for information on AAC funding and a template for a funding report Guidelines for Use of AAC
contraindications precautions to test: The SLP needs to be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communication and literacy and when developing treatment goals.(9) Communication and literacy needs of the child should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting(9)

contraindications precautions to examina: The SLP needs to be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communication and literacy and when developing treatment goals.(9) Communication and literacy needs of the child should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting(9)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Does the child have a diagnosis? When was the diagnosis made and by whom? A developmental or intellectual delay is often diagnosed over a period of time rather than at a single clinical encounter.(10) Does the child have a documented learning disability or reading difficulty? How long has the child been using AAC?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management will vary with respect to the etiology of the disorder and presenting symptoms. Does the child have a history of prolonged hospitalization? What kind of medical management has the child received, including surgeries, medication, and rehabilitation?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests related to the need for AAC in children with reading difficulties are the following:
Formal and informal speech and language assessment (for further information, see Relevant tests and measures , below)
Comprehensive reading assessment (for further information, see Relevant tests and measures , below)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., computerbased  reading programs) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech-language  therapy, special education support, occupational therapy, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Are there times of the day during which the child’s communication is better or worse? -Does the child have any challenging behaviors that interfere with socialization with peers or participation in the classroom?(4) -Does the child communicate more clearly with certain persons or in certain situations? -Does the child have fine or gross motor impairments that affect ability to communicate and participate in class?(4) -Does the child have hearing or vision impairments? -How does the child interact with peers in the classroom? -Is the child exposed to a literacy-rich  home and/or school environment? (e.g., Is the child read to or exposed to books on a daily basis? Are there discussions of the alphabet and letter sounds?) -Does the child read? Are there types of texts that the child prefers (computer-based,  print-based, genre)?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: The symptoms of reading difficulties in children who use an AAC system are highly variable and might be influenced by the child’s diagnosis, the child’s age, the severity of accompanying motor or cognitive impairments, the child’s medical status, the child’s classroom placement and instruction, and the child’s home environment. Children with physical and developmental disabilities might have problems in the areas of producing vocalizations and/or speech, receptive language, expressive language (including the use of gestures), and/or social language (pragmatics) that can affect their ability to participate in literacy activities(3,11)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document any sleep disturbances. Sleep disturbances are common in children with intellectual disability (ID). Factors that contribute to sleep disturbances are obesity, enlarged tonsils, gastroesophageal reflux (GER), and lack of sufficient exercise/activity(12)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Examples include hemianopia (partial blindness), depression, motor deficits, dysphagia, apraxia, dysarthria, poor overall health status, and seizures
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient have respiratory difficulties? Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube? A family’s needs and priorities should be discussed during an assessment, either formally or informally -Problem behaviors among children with developmental disabilities are higher than among those with typical development, with the highest levels found in children with ASD and cerebral palsy(13) -Parental stress has been found to be associated with syndrome-specific  behavioral patterns(13)Has the child’s hearing been screened? If hearing loss is suspected, refer to an audiologist for a full evaluation -Children with hearing loss have increased difficulty developing literacy skills. For children to understand what they have read, they need to be able to use what they know about spoken language; hence, children with hearing loss and language disorders can have difficulty not only with sounding out letters and words, but with reading comprehension as well. In order to promote literacy in a child with hearing loss, the parents, teachers, and SLP should collaborate to create a literacy-rich  environment for the child. Speech therapy and AAC training can focus on both spoken language and reading development simultaneously Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the child been seen by any other specialist for developmental delay in any area? Is there a family history of developmental disability?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient’s family/caregivers about other problems, including behavior problems, motor difficulties, or selfinjurious  behavior. Children with developmental and intellectual disabilities are at risk for having Etiology-specific  comorbidities (e.g., children with Down syndrome are at risk for hearing impairment, vision difficulties, celiac disease, hypothyroidism)(12)20% to 30% of children with ID also have a diagnosis of ASD(12)9% to 15% of children with ID also have ADHD(12)The prevalence of sensory impairments in children with mild ID is 2%; in children with severe ID, it is 11%(12)The prevalence of psychiatric and behavioral disturbances in children with ID is estimated to be as high as 80%(12)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient and/or family/caregivers about other symptoms the patient is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Things to consider include -Does the child currently receive intervention services? If so, are they home, school, or clinic based? -What is the school placement? Classroom, small group, 1-on-1  aide? -What kind of toys or activities is the child most interested in?  -How does the child communicate thoughts, wants, and needs in various settings and with various communication partners (e.g., gestures, eye gaze, vocalizations, words)?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: The absence of functional communication can significantly impact a child’s ability to participate in ADLs. During an assessment, the SLP should consider ways to support a child’s participation in ADLs, including literacy activities during the school day. This should be done in collaboration with the patient, family/caregiver, other medical personnel, and school/work staff(14) -What ADLs can the child perform? -At what age were developmental milestones reached?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives (e.g., family, caregivers). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? What language does the patient speak at home? Inquire about the literacy environment of the home. What types of books are available to the child? How much time is spent reading to/with the child? How do other members of the household use literacy materials, what type and with what frequency? How often does the child use an AAC system at home?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Does the patient have any hemiparesis, paralysis, or other motor difficulties that might affect ability to use an AAC device? Refer to an occupational therapist (OT) or physical therapist (PT) for an access evaluation if needed
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Additional specific tests might be required for specific diagnoses. For example, 50% of children with cerebral palsy have dysarthria with symptoms such as shallow, irregular breathing for speech; low-pitched,  harsh-sounding  voice; and minimal pitch variation.(27) For detailed information on speech assessment/Speech Therapy ;T708777
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)If the child uses some speech for communication, use a standardized test or an informal (nonstandardized) analysis to determine errors that have a high frequency of occurrence. For specific sounds, the number of omissions, substitutions, distortions, and additions can be completed. A sound inventory can be completed for children who have severely limited speech. For detailed information on speech sound disorders in children, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic  –Language -SLPs should always supplement standardized tests with informal language assessment procedures to assess students’ pragmatic, social, and functional communication abilities -If the parents/caregivers speak another language at home (L1), it is important to complete the assessment in that language as well as in the language used in the child’s school. For detailed information on assessment of bilingualBilingual School-Aged Children ; CINAHL Topic IDT709066 -Tests might have to be adapted so that the child can respond by pointing or by using the AAC device. Tests might need to be further adapted for students who are unable to provide oral, text-based,  or pointing responses. For example, if a receptive language tasks includes f possible answers, the answers can be numbered and the numbers 1-4 can be placed on a board and the child can choose by using eye gaze(19) -Many standardized language tests include separate standardized scores for children with mild ID. However, no general language tests include students with more severe ID in the normative sample.(20) Standardized tests that provide -Clinical Evaluation of Language Fundamentals, 5th edition (CELF-5)(21) -Comprehensive Assessment of Spoken Language (CASL)(22) -Expressive One-Word  Picture V ocabulary Test (EOWPVT) -Oral and Written Language Scales (OWLS)(23) -Test of Early Language Development, 3rd edition (TELD-3)(24) -Test of Language Development–Intermediate,  3rd edition (TOLD-I)(25)Rule out or identify the presence of a voice disorderNote any history of fluency disorder (e.g., childhood-onset  fluency disorder)Adapt formal and informal reading assessments as needed to match the child’s physical capabilities (e.g., pointing might not be possible). For example, if the child uses a scanning system, place test items in a format to be scanned by eye gaze rather than read or pointed to (see below for examples). Reading assessment should be developmentally –Letter identification –Sound-letter  identification –Word reading -In a study conducted in Australia of 40 adults with physical and/or intellectual disability, word-reading  tasks that did not require spoken responses were developed and administered to determine construct validity of the items.(19) TasksThe participant was asked to listen to a word and match it with the written format (out of two choices) by using eye gaze to select the correct word mounted on a Perspex board(19)The participant was asked to listen to a nonword (e.g., dusp) and match it with the written format (dusp or dosp) by using eye gaze to select the correct nonword mounted on a Perspex board(19)A written word was mounted at the center of a Perspex board and five picture cards were placed at the corners and top edge of the board. The participant was asked to read the word aloud or silently and select the corresponding picture mounted on a board by eye gaze(19) –Phonemic awareness (PA) -In the same study from Australia of 40 adults with physical disabilities and/or intellectual disability, phonemic awareness tasks that did not require spoken responses were developed and administered to determine construct validity of the items. Despite slight differences in task administration (as compared to those requiring oral responses),(19)three pictures were presented on a large Perspex sheet and participants were instructed to look at the relevant picture card that matched the auditory stimulus of segmented sounds (e.g., f-ee-t  → feet)participants were asked to listen to segmented sounds of nonwords such as “g-u-k”  and the correct (“guk”) or incorrect (“gobe”) nonword and indicate by “yes” or “no” if the segmented sounds matched the nonword that followed(19) Participants were asked to determine the number of phonemes in a word spoken by the examiner by looking at the correct number on the Perspex board(1,3,4)Participants were asked to identify individual phonemes in specific words by listening to phonemes and two words and indicating by eye gaze which of two pictured words contained the phoneme they had just heard. Phonemes were placed in the initial, medial, and final positions of the words(19)With respect to reading, fluency is the ability to read aloud with speed, accuracy, and proper expression.(26) A child who uses an AAC device will most likely not be able to read aloud fluently and quickly. The SLP or teacher might choose to measure speed of reading by timing the participant as he/she reads silently and then asking comprehension questions or asking the student to summarize the textResponses for reading comprehension tasks might be adapted in the same ways as above. The participant might indicate from a choice of answers by eye gaze, pointing, or the use of a device (e.g., switch) –Assessment of writing/spelling (e.g., can be assessed with spelling/keyboard function through AAC device or eye gaze to a correctly spelled word from field of three)Children of all ages with developmental and physical disabilities can have feeding and swallowing difficulties. For detailed information on assessment and treatment of feeding and swallowing associated with a specific disorder, please see the series of Clinical Reviews on pediatric feeding and swallowing disorders
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: The SLP might administer language-related problem-solving  tests, but other cognitive tests will be most likely administered by a school psychologist or special education teacher (e.g., the School Inventory of Problem-Solving  Skills [SIPSS])(15)
relevant tests and measures.aac assessment: The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) recommends that the approach to AAC assessment follow the participation model, which is based on the fact that all persons with disabilities can enhance communication ability.(1,16) The goal of an AAC assessment within the participation model is to match the child with optimal communication strategies and systems so that he or she can participate in meaningful events in daily life.(1) Assessment must consider the skills of the child as well as the setting and prospective conversational partners. A team approach is recommended in the implementation of AAC; team members typically include SLPs, teachers, the AAC user, and parents/caregivers. To the greatest extent possible, assessment procedures should be applicable to everyday life(1, 6)The purpose of an environmental assessment is to determine the extent of the child’s communication repertoire and social functions with respect to the child’s peers and to identify potential(16) -A peer might be observed in a particular setting (e.g., classroom). The SLP charts the list of communication and participation behaviors that were required for a particular activity(16) -The communication abilities of the child being considered for AAC are compared(16) -Potential communicative and participation barriers are identified. Interviews with the child’s caregivers, teachers, and other communicative partners might identify possible communication barriers that can be resolved. In addition, systematic observation of the child’s interactions, with focus on the communicative partners, can yield information on barriers that might limit the child’s opportunity to communicate. Sample barriers might include lack of sufficient response time allowed for child, lack of child attention during communicative interactions, and environmental barriers such as presence of loud noises in the classroom(16) -The child is then provided the AAC support and taught the skills necessary to participate in the activity(16) -Positioning and location for each activity should be considered when selecting an AAC system(18) -Communication functions and specific messages (e.g., sharing information with classmates, asking for assistance) should be considered when selecting and programming an AAC device(18)
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. For detailed information on assessment of patients with tracheostomies, see ClinicalChildren with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number on assessment of a tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir Tracheostomy &T708919

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Children with developmental and physical disabilities might be at risk for feeding and swallowing disorders; perform a feeding/swallowing evaluation if feeding/swallowing disorders are suspected or if the child exhibits signs of malnourishment

Children with developmental and physical disabilities might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and parents/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. If inpatient, hospital discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for procedure Diagnosis of a reading delay or identification of a child at risk for a reading delay is based upon a comprehensive assessment that examines the child’s present communicative skills, communicative needs, reading/writing abilities, and future reading/writing needs AAC intervention should be a multidisciplinary and ongoing procedure that might require multiple systems over many years to accommodate changing cognitive, linguistic, and physical abilities(28) Goals should be developed by an AAC team that includes, at minimum, the SLP, the family, a teacher, and the student.(29) The multidisciplinary team should address language, literacy, and occupational and physical therapy goals together when appropriate(30)(31) –The child has socially unacceptable or harmful ways of communicating (e.g., hitting)(1,31)  –Existing methods of communication are inefficient or tiring for the child(1,31) –Existing methods of communication are understood only by a limited number of familiar conversational partners(1,31)
prognosis: The overall prognosis for a child with developmental disability depends on the presence of numerous variables that can negatively affect literacy learning, including the severity of motor impairments, cognitive impairments, psychosocial deficits, visual or hearing impairments, speech and language impairments, lack of experience and world knowledge, history of lack of participation in literacy activities, and accompanying health problems. Adaptive skill development can also have a significant impact on the child’s future level of independence(12,49)

Prognosis for AAC use depends on the above intrinsic factors as well as external factors that might be barriers to or facilitators of AAC use. Barriers that have been identified include time constraints, specific device problems, and lack of support from parents/guardians(6)

Prognosis related to literacy learning among children who use AAC is influenced by accurate assessments of the individual’s reading skills as well as exposure to and access to literacy experiences and evidence-based  literacy instruction.(3) Many children who use AAC have inconsistent and limited literacy experiences and receive the majority of their literacy instruction outside of the general education classroom. Children who rely on AAC have fewer literacy experiences in the classroom and at home than their peers without disabilities. In addition, the quality of these literacy experiences also differs, with the children who rely on AAC having fewer opportunities to participate in meaningful ways in literacy activities.(49) Balanced literacy programs that are effective for children who do not use AAC have also been shown to increase communication and literacy skills in children who use AAC(3)

Many children and adults who use AAC have low literacy skills and their difficulties cannot be adequately explained or predicted by the presence of severe speech impairments or their cognitive and linguistic functioning.(44) Not all individuals who use AAC experience difficulties in reading and spelling –Researchers in Sweden and Ireland sought to explain the variability in literacy abilities among AAC users by examining the similarities and differences among groups of good readers, single-word  readers (“decoders”),and nonreaders.(44) All 28 participants had cerebral palsy, used AAC, and were described as functioning in the average range of intellectual ability. Participants were given two single-word  vocabulary tests, a measure of nonverbal cognition, and researcher-developed  phonological awareness, reading, and spelling measures. The researchers analyzed and compared all three groups’ performance on phonological awareness, spelling, reading, and memory tasks. Findings of this study indicated: -There was no single factor that could account for reading ability -There was no obvious relationship between type of schooling, speech ability, and reading proficiency -Working memory skills are important in the early stage of reading development; however, there was no significant difference in phonological short-term memory scores between good readers and decoders -The good readers achieved significantly higher spelling scores than the decoders -The researchers concluded that future research should focus on developing sensitive diagnostic tools to profile individual reading abilities and on identifying effective instructional practices for this population
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Several professionals might be involved in the school assessment and treatment team for a child with a physical or developmental disability:(3)An OT can assist with fine motor and adaptive skills. Collaborate with the OT on AAC support as necessary (e.g., optimal way to access the device) and participation barriers caused by fine motor impairments(4)Refer to a PT if the child has significant motor deficits and/or poor/weak posture that negatively affect speech production, class participation, and overall health. The PT might consult on integrating physical therapy goals into the daily routine. For example, positioning is often a concern for children with severe developmental and physical disabilities and is often an important part of the daily physical therapy program (e.g., standing in a support frame, lying stomach down).(30) The SLP and teacher should be aware of the physical effort involved in therapeutic physical tasks and pair more difficult physical activities with less demanding cognitive tasks (listening to a story for pleasure)(30)A recreational therapist might be involved with the team to assist the child in developing recreational skillsSocial services can assist the family in negotiating assistance systems (e.g., medical services, daycare)Refer to a behavioral psychologist if the child exhibits any challenging behaviors, including self-injurious behaviors
treatment summary: Overall considerations –Effective literacy intervention for the child who uses AAC requires early support of language to prepare the child for development of early literacy skills(6,29) –A coordinated effort among teachers, the SLP, the family, and the child is important for effective and efficient use of AAC at home and in the classroom(6,29) –A balanced literacy curriculum that includes development of phonemic awareness, vocabulary, word recognition, decoding, fluency, reading comprehension, and writing using a range of literacy tasks has been found to be effective for individuals who use AAC as well as for those who do not use AAC(3,26) –Rather than a single system of communication, the assessment team should identify multiple methods of communication that the child might use in different situations.(29) Some forms of AAC (e.g., manual signs) are more easily accessed but understood only by some communication partners; voice output communication aids (VOCAs) are more widely understood but might not be available at the moment that the child wants to communicate

Team consultation and collaboration –The SLP might be involved in instructing teachers/paraeducators/peers and/or parents on how to use the AAC system with the child. Instruction will vary with the individual’s knowledge but might include the importance of communication, the relationship between behavior and communication, prompting students/peers to use AAC, and how to recognize and respond to the child’s communicative attempts(32) –The SLP might work with the team in adapting the curriculum, adapting assessment tools, operating/programming the AAC system, and selecting appropriate vocabulary

Assessment, selection, programming, instruction, and monitoring of the AAC system: AAC is typically categorized into unaided systems of communication and aided systems of communication –Unaided approaches to AAC involve using the child’s body to communicate by means of manual signs, gestures, vocalizations, facial expressions, or body movements(33) –Aided communication approaches include light-technology devices and high-technology  devices(33) –Light-technology  AAC refers to nonelectronic external devices such as alphabet boards, symbol-based  topic boards, dry erase boards, and programs such as the Picture Exchange Communication System (PECS) –High-technology  systems are electronic devices such as speech-generating  systems. Speech-generating  devices have been classified into two main types: devices that allow for formation of new messages and devices that use word or whole-phrase  retrieval of prerecorded messages. Caregivers and patients should be involved in selecting the device –Modeling of the use of the device/system is an essential part of the instructional process. The teacher/SLP/caregiver models the AAC system and integrates the system in his or her own communication interactions, literacy activities, and/or book discussions during naturalistic and motivating situations. Modeling allows input experience for the child(34) –Factors to consider when selecting and programming a high-technology  or light-technology  device include: -V ocabulary/symbol considerations -When selecting vocabulary for use with the AAC system, the SLP/teacher should consider the child’s preferences and functional motivations as well as vocabulary to support the child’s participation in literacy activities and other classroom activities(3) -Target vocabulary used with the AAC system should be salient to the child and able to be modeled in educational, naturalistic, routine, and motivating situations(34) -When introducing new symbols, routine situations should be used so that the child’s attention can be focused on learning the new word rather than understanding a novel situation(34) -When choosing vocabulary to use with AAC, it is important to use people’s names as well as social phrases (e.g., my turn, what’s that, I don’t like it, I want more) to encourage social closeness(4,34) -Emotion labels are important for the child to talk about school and other past events. They also allow the child to communicate when frustrated(34) -Inclusion of action words will help foster more complex syntactic development or symbol combinations(34)  -The system should also be programmed or designed to encourage participation across a range of literacy tasks such as phonological awareness, spelling, guided reading, and independent reading and writing. For example, a child who uses a communication board might have different boards for different classroom activities (e.g., calendar time, circle time) so that responses can be easily located(4) -Access considerations -There are two ways of indicating symbols with aided AAC systems, direct selection and scanning. Direct selection involves the child directly selecting the symbol (i.e., using a finger, using eye gaze). For those who have difficulty with motor control, scanning might be used(34) -There are two kinds of scanning: partner assisted and electronic. In electronic scanning, the AAC device presents the choices electronically. For example, a light might go on next to each symbol one-by-one.  When a light indicates the desired symbol, the child selects it by hitting a switch.(34) Some devices allow for direct selection or scanning -In partner-assisted  scanning, the communication partner scans through symbols one-by-one  (i.e., by pointing). When the partner arrives at the desired choice, the child can indicate by vocalizing, moving an arm, or using an eyeblink(34) -Display presentation considerations -Presentation refers to the organization and layout of the concepts within a display. Variables in presentation include the permanence of the display (i.e., static vs. dynamic display), layout of the display (i.e., grid or visual scene displays), number of representations on the display, size of the symbols, and color organization(35) -In a static display, all symbols can be viewed simultaneously but are limited in number. In a dynamic display, the person can navigate different electronic or nonelectronic pages to find other symbols(35) -Symbols can be displayed on a grid (rows and columns of pictures) or as a visual scene display. A visual scene display contains a picture or photograph with hot spots that allow the user to select items within the scene. For example, a scene might be a kitchen and the user might select an item of food. It is theorized that visual scene displays might reduce cognitive demands in finding and using correct symbols because the symbols are displayed in a meaningful context.(35) Preliminary research indicates that young children perform more accurately when communication symbols are embedded in meaningful contexts and depict full representations of familiar persons and objects(45) -Recent AAC applications developed for use on mainstream devices (mobile phones with texting, iPads, iTouch) have made AAC more affordable and more available, and have also given users an opportunity to “blend in.”(45,47) For example, researchers who conducted a study in Sweden found that texting with picture symbols and speech increased independence and participation in adults with complex communication needs and intellectual disabilities.(48) However, researchers cautioned that only minimal research has focused on improving the design of AAC technologies to maximize outcomes for children. Most of the available mobile technology apps have replicated traditional AAC interfaces that were developed in the early years of AAC and most are not based on research evidence. There is a need to develop a new generation of AAC systems that are responsive to the needs of children who use them(45)

Preliteracy and literacy interventions for children who use AAC –Preliteracy interventions: Storybook reading is an important activity in emergent literacy and language learning in which a parent, teacher, or older child reads a text to a child and talks about the story, relating it to the child’s experiences while the child listens to the story, comments on events, relates the story to his/her life, asks questions and/or retells part of the story. During this activity, the child is exposed to a wide range of grammar and vocabulary and has the opportunity to talk about events and concepts not immediately present in the environment (“displaced talk”)(49) –Storybook reading interactions with children with AAC have been found to be qualitatively different from those with children with typically developing communication. Typically developing children often choose the book themselves and choose the same book. In contrast, parents are often the ones choosing the book for the child who uses AAC. As a result, shared book reading sessions might not be as responsive to the needs and interests of the child. Also, children who use AAC do not usually have access to AAC during story reading interactions, reducing their ability to communicate and learn emergent literacy skills(49) -Researchers in the United States investigated the effects of a communication partner instruction strategy for parents of children using AAC during storybook-reading  contexts in two single-subject multiple-probe-across-participants design studies with six parent/child dyads.(43) The program, Improving Partner Applications of Augmentative Communication Techniques (ImPAACT), was designed to facilitate early language and communication skills in children who use ACC. Techniques included in the program were parent-provided  AAC model, parent-asked wh-question, parent-answered  wh-question,  parent provided an expectant delay. Child-dependent  measures included  the total number of communicative turns during each 10-minute  story reading session. Results indicated that all of the parents achieved a high level of competency using the communication partner interaction strategy. All of the children increased the number of turns that they took while reading stories -Researchers in the United States compared the vocabulary used by 29 typically developing kindergartners while being read a story with vocabulary on commercially available storybook communication displays marketed for individuals with AAC needs.(46) They found that vocabulary on commercially available displays did not include vocabulary most used by kindergartners and that communication displays might need to be modified to provide sufficient vocabulary to allow participation during storybook reading activities –Literacy interventions -Literacy intervention for children using AAC has been criticized for being too teacher-directed  and reactive rather than child-directed  and constructive(30) -Authors of a systematic review published in 2018 of literacy interventions for individuals who use AAC reported findings from 9 studies involving a total of 24 subjects. Authors found that overall, reading instruction did have positive effects on single-word reading ability. Results indicated that phonological approaches, sight-word  approaches, and a combination of both of these approaches showed very large effect sizes; however, generalizability of results was limited due to small studies and heterogenous study populations(2) -Authors of a systematic review evaluated 8 single-subject  design studies that taught phonological awareness and individual-word  reading to a total of 26 children who used AAC.(42) The authors did not form any conclusions regarding the best practices. Studies described a variety of reading instructions tasks (sound matching, sound categorization, phoneme identification, spelling, word identification, phoneme segmentation, word identification) and listed a variety of modifications: pointing to a picture of a word, pointing to a letter after hearing a phoneme, using tiles printed with letters or typing on a keyboard, using markers on a table to indicate phonemes. Review authors recommended the development of standard phonological-awareness  and reading assessments for this population. They also reported a need to replicate the results of effective reading interventions across different contexts and groups of children and advocated a central database to aggregate the results of research studies -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers examined the effectiveness of a strategy to teach sound-letter correspondence and spelling of consonant-vowel-consonant  (CVC) combinations to two young children who used AAC in inclusive preschool classrooms.(47) Components of the intervention included: 1) arranging the environment to create adult-directed  teaching and active teacher-child  interactions to learn sound-letter correspondence (literacy centers with an adult at the CVC center), 2) providing adaptations to support the active participation of children using AAC (child points to letter or letter combination after the adult says the sound), and 3) using “naturalistic” instructional strategies. Naturalistic instructional strategies include arranging the environment, providing antecedent prompts to facilitate learning with minimal errors, and being responsive to a learner’s interests and behaviors. Both participants exhibited significant improvement in learning CVC combinations -In a small study (N = 3) conducted in the United States, researchers investigated the use of the alphabet supplementation technique, typically used to increase comprehension in listeners with low speech intelligibility, for increasing both speech intelligibility and literacy in adults with disabilities. All three individuals in this study used AAC due to low speech intelligibility, but also had minimal literacy. Researchers found that training initial-letter  identification for a core set of words both improved reading vocabulary and increased understanding of communication by listeners (50) –Literacy intervention for individuals who use AAC should be guided by the same principles as evidence-based  literacy interventions for other individuals who struggle with reading; the need for oral responses during instruction should be reduced and/or eliminated, and the integration of AAC systems with instruction is essential.(26,36) For detailed information on preliteracy intervention, please see Clinical Review…Language Disorders: Preschool Children (Preliteracy Skills) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709110 and Clinical Review…Reading Disabilities: Early Elementary School-Aged Children ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709075 ›See Description/use, Indications , and Guidelines for Use of AAC , above. . Early literacy experiences are essential for developing literacy skills and can be adapted using the AAC system. The SLP can train communication partners (family members, teachers, peers, or paraeducators) to adapt interactive story-book reading activities to the child’s skills: –Allow the child to choose books of interest(49) –Introduce the topic of the book by discussing related experiences(49) –Model the use of the AAC system while reading a text. The AAC system might include a VOCA which produces a line from the text or pictures/ symbols that represent content words(38) –Pause and provide sufficient wait time for the child to participate in the reading activity –Model using the AAC system while asking open-ended questions related to the book and the child’s experiences –Respond to the communication attempts of the child –The AAC system might have to be specifically programmed with vocabulary needed to participate in story-book reading activities(46) –Read the same book repeatedly to encourage the child to retell parts of the story(49)The child will increase responses during shared storybook activities and will increase knowledge of vocabulary, print materials, and narrativesParents/caregivers can be instructed on how to modify shared story- book reading at home  Poor phonemic awareness (PA) skillsIncrease the child’s PA skillsAdapt PA instruction to the skills of the child _ The following are ways that PA skills can be adapted to children who use AAC:(49) _ _ Phoneme matching task: The instructor says a sound (/b/) and presents four pictures. The instructor asks child to indicate which picture begins with the sound /b/ by the method that is appropriate for the child (e.g., a VOCA, communication board, eye pointing to the picture that begins with the target sound). This task can be done with both initial and final phonemes _ _ Sound-blending task: The instructor presents individual sounds of a word in segments (m---a---n). The child is asked to select a picture by eye gaze (out of four) that matches the word formed by joining the segmented sounds(49) _The child will improve performance on PA tasks such as identifying initial and final sounds in words and blending words. The child will then use these skills in single- word reading and in beginning writing skills(37)None specified  Poor letter-sound knowledgeIncrease ability of child to understand letter- sound correspondenceAdapt letter/sound instruction tasks to the skills of the child _ Present an array of letters in a format that allows the child to choose specific letters. For example, say “Touch the letter that says /m/" or "Touch the letters that spell 'mat'.” The child can touch, point, use eye gaze, or use his/her dedicated AAC system to indicate letters. If letters are printed on a computer, be sure that the font matches the style used in the classroom so that it is more easily recognizable and generalizable (e.g., a sans-serif font). Provide modeling and scaffolding as necessary(36) _Progression will vary with the abilities of the child. Evidence- based reading programs specify the scope and sequence of letter/ sound instruction; these programs can be followed and adapted for the child who uses AAC. The instructor can say the word or provide a picture and have the child choose the correct written word. Researchers have investigated the effects of teaching word recognition and word decoding to students with AAC with results indicating improved reading skills.(39,40) Computer programs can also provide further practice with word reading(39) _Progression will vary with the abilities of the child. In addition, materials such as taped books, computerized books, audiobooks, video, and role plays/theater can be used to enhance comprehension. Language and literacy goals should both be considered when choosing books and texts for comprehension activities. During classroom reading activities, the child should be given the opportunity to participate (e.g., programming specific lines into AAC device) _Progression will vary with the abilities of the child. For example, the child might begin with simple words and phrases and progress to connected textHomework might include shared-book reading with parent/ caregiver to improve both language and reading comprehension  Poor writing ability Increase child’s ability to write/convey ideas through writingAdapt writing activities to skills of the child _ A range of writing activities should be integrated into the daily curricula. Possible ways the SLP might support the child’s writing development include:(41) –Identifying the best way that the child can compose text. This might include a combination of high-tech and low-tech systems (e.g., eye gaze frame, Dynavox, an alternative keyboard, an alternative mouse system) –Ensuring that the vocabulary in the AAC system/s support a range of writing tasks –Ensuring that the AAC system/s can be used easily for both communication and assigned writing tasks, allowing the child to move easily between oral and written tasks as he/ she is composing –Assisting with home-school communication to provide experiences that the child can write about. Formats of information transfer include activity logs, journals, remnants, and photographs –Assisting in building background knowledge of the child to support writing –Provide scaffolding (provide enough assistance so that the child can complete task at his/her level) or instruct a paraeducator to provide scaffolding for the child during writing tasks –Assist the child in publishing or sharing his or her written work with the class. Examples of progressive tasks include increasing independence with writing activities; progressing from simpler writing activities (single word labeling a picture) to more complex writing activities (sentences, paragraphs)The SLP or teacher might assist with home- school communication to provide experiences about which the child can write. Formats of information transfer include activity logs, journals, remnants, and photographs.(41) As the child progresses with writing skills, written homework can be completed at home  .

maintenance or prevention: In a qualitative study conducted in Canada of interviews with six special education teachers and one SLP who worked together on a school AAC team, researchers identified three factors that facilitated AAC use: Parent participation in the team process: AAC use was considered more successful when there was consistent communication between parents and school, when parents used the device with the child at home, and when parents participated in decision-making(6) Effective team collaboration: Respondents reported that effective teaming required time, frequent communication, shared goals of building communication skills of students, administrative support for meetings and equipment needs, and support from all staff who were working with the students using AAC(6) Ease of use of device: Ease of use refers not only to ease of student use (e.g., portability, durability) but also ease of programming and maintenance(6)

Factors related to abandonment of AAC system include poor performance with the device, lack of significant improvement in communication with the device, high costs associated with the device (service, repair, maintenance), and limited availability of service and repair(1) Patient/Caregiver Education
